subject: Re: [junit] Re: Integrating Jemmy and JUnit
msgSnippet: Hi Dave, hi Nathan, ... From: Dave Astels  ... From: Nathan Paris  ... dialog.  The jemmy code will thrown and
messageBody:
Hi Dave, hi Nathan,

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Astels" <dave@...>
> What I've done is use the Jemmy wrappers etc. to manipulate/query the
> UI from withing a test... set it up, do something, assert the results.
> If there are structural failures (e.g. a certain widget can't be
> found) Jemmy throws an excption with the test runner catches & reports
> as an error.
>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Nathan Paris" <nsparis@...>
> I enter the value and then invoke the correct button and wait for the
dialog. The jemmy code will thrown and exception if it doesnt appear.
>
> try{
> JDialogOperator dialog = new JDialogOperator( dialogTitle );
> }catch( Exception e ){
> fail( "Failed to show dialog" );
> }

From browsing the Jemmy examples and duplicating them, I got the impression
that one has to implement the Scenario interface and then call Test.main().
From what you both write I take it this is not the case, right? One can just
use the Jemmy classes standalone. This makes using Jemmy from within JUnit
much easier than I thought it was.

Thanks, Johannes
